stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on Course 11, 'Oily Boily Bay'. The stream focused on designing, modeling, and programming a new wind turbine mechanic to be used in the level's red coin mission. He also encountered and solved a significant technical 'gimbal lock' issue, discussed his game design philosophies, and reflected on his YouTube content strategy.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is debating the difficulty of the final level, wanting to create a very challenging 'Kaizo' style experience but worrying it will frustrate casual players trying to complete the game.
development_findings.quote: The thing is people are going to try to 100% them and if there's one thing that is much more difficult than the rest of the game people are going to get really frustrated with it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a design philosophy against offering numerous minor cosmetic or gameplay options (e.g., font, health bar style), believing it dilutes the intended experience and is not a worthwhile development effort.
development_findings.quote: People are asking for more options than are worth it. Like, they are asking for options on every little detail... At that point, just make your own game.

development_findings.summary: To solve a gimbal lock issue preventing a turbine model from rotating on the correct axis, Kaze had to create a new, separate 3D model that was pre-rotated in Blender.
development_findings.quote: We have to rotate it in the 3D model and make it another separate model. And now it will work.

development_findings.summary: The game's camera was changed based on feedback from someone named Lilaa, demonstrating that direct feedback can lead to core gameplay adjustments.
development_findings.quote: Lilaa was complaining about it and I kind of saw her point.

development_findings.summary: Kaze notes that the development of Course 11 ('Oily Boily Bay') is more improvisational than other levels, with platforming mechanics and layouts being created spontaneously during the stream.
development_findings.quote: Yeah, this level is a bit improvised compared to my normal levels. We're kind of making a lot of shit up on the fly.

development_findings.summary: A change was made to the game's camera system between streams based on external feedback.
development_findings.quote: Yeah, we changed the camera since last time to The camera slightly different

development_findings.summary: Kaze proudly demonstrates Course 1 running with a vastly increased draw distance, achieving a visual style he feels approaches a GameCube title, though it causes FPS to drop to ~20 in demanding scenes.
development_findings.quote: This is an N64 game. How crazy is that?

development_findings.summary: The project is currently using 42.8MB of its 64MB ROM size limit.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the YouTube algorithm now favors long, verbose 'background noise' content over concise, engaging videos, a theory he developed after his April Fool's video outperformed his more serious, high-effort technical content.
context_findings.quote: I have the theory that right now Youtube is in the background noise meta. You're not supposed to make engaging videos. You're supposed to make videos that can be listened to while they're in the background and that is what will get you the views.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration and feels insulted that his low-effort April Fool's video about 'touching grass' received significantly more views than his serious videos about technical advancements in N64 programming.
context_findings.quote: This stupid fucking meme video, 160k. This revolutionizing N64 programming, less than fucking Grass April Fool's video.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reflects on the changing online climate, noting that the edgy humor of his 2016 romhack 'Super Trump 64' would likely be received poorly today, making him hesitant to remake it.
context_findings.quote: Back in 2016, you could make stupid edgy jokes and it was funny. 2024? I don't know how funny it would be. Because I feel like a lot of people would actually be very upset.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions his bike was recently stolen, which put him in a bad mood at the start of the stream.
Kaze expresses a personal financial philosophy of being frugal and preferring to save money rather than make purchases.
context_findings.quote: I hate buying stuff. I like having money.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is trying to transition his streams from Twitch to YouTube and is encouraged by the high viewer count on this stream, seeing it as a positive sign for the move.

biobak.summary: Kaze mentions needing a specific texture file from Biobak ('volley just face'), indicating direct collaboration on art assets for the level.
biobak.quote: Right, so I looked into that file back. I don't know if I have the original file for it anymore. I think it's just the texture I have but I'll look again before I forget.

key_stories.title: The Gimbal Lock Turbine
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent a significant amount of time fighting with the game engine's Euler angle rotations, a problem known as gimbal lock. After failing to rotate a turbine model correctly in-engine, he had to resort to creating a new, pre-rotated 3D model in Blender as a workaround.
key_stories.challenge: A turbine model needed to be rotated horizontally for a platforming mechanic, but the game engine's controls for pitch, roll, and yaw were all rotating it on the wrong axes.
key_stories.process: Kaze first attempted to use the in-engine rotation parameters (pitch, roll, and yaw). After discovering they were all affected by gimbal lock and wouldn't produce the desired horizontal rotation, he expressed frustration and recalled a similar issue from the past. He concluded the only solution was to modify the source model itself.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze solved the problem by creating a duplicate 3D model in Blender, rotating it by 90 degrees, and importing it as a separate asset specifically for horizontal turbines. This workaround successfully bypassed the gimbal lock issue.
key_stories.key_quote: That is fucked up. That is like the most fucked up game engine ever. I hate Euler angles.

key_stories.title: The 'Funny Wahoo Man' Dilemma
key_stories.summary: Frustrated by his serious technical videos underperforming, Kaze analyzed his YouTube stats live on stream. He concluded that meme-worthy, 'funny Wahoo man' content and clickbait titles are necessary for channel growth, forcing him to reconsider his content strategy.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze's high-effort, technical development videos on YouTube were receiving far fewer views than a low-effort April Fool's meme video, causing him frustration.
key_stories.process: Kaze directly compared the view counts of his videos, highlighting the massive discrepancy. This led to a discussion about the YouTube algorithm, where he theorized that long, less-engaging content performs better. He then workshopped new, more clickbaity video titles suggested by his audience.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze concluded that to grow his channel, he must adapt to the YouTube 'meta' by creating more 'background noise' content and using clickbait-style titles, even if it feels insulting to his serious work. He brainstormed several such video ideas with his chat.
key_stories.key_quote: They don't want to see code, they want to see the funny Wahoo man jump.

key_stories.title: Creating the Wind Turbines
key_stories.summary: To add more dynamic platforming to 'Oily Boily Bay', Kaze took inspiration from plane engines to create wind turbines. He went through the full process of concepting, modeling, texturing, and coding the new mechanic live on stream, turning an idea into a functional gameplay element.
key_stories.challenge: While brainstorming new platforming mechanics for Course 11, Kaze felt the level needed more variety beyond simple platforms.
key_stories.process: Kaze looked for inspiration, considering oil spots from Sonic's Oil Ocean zone before settling on the idea of plane engines or turbines. He then modeled a basic turbine in Blender, textured it, and wrote the C code to control its behavior, including its rotation, on/off timer, and the physics force applied to Mario.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze designed and implemented both vertical and horizontal wind turbines that turn on and off in intervals, creating timing-based platforming challenges and puzzles for the level's red coin mission.
key_stories.key_quote: What do you think of wind turbines? Like not like this but somewhat like this I guess... a plane engine that's what I was looking for.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions the current blue coin switch model is 'super ugly' and that they are 'still stuck with the shitty version'. He briefly considered a design from Super Mario Sunshine but also disliked it.
questions: What have been the main challenges in designing a blue coin switch that fits the game's aesthetic?
What different designs has the team tried so far?
Who on the team is responsible for the final design, and what is the approval process like for a key asset like this?

open_questions.context: A person named 'Lilaa' is mentioned as having complained about the camera, leading to a change. She also gave feedback on model 'cutouts'.
questions: Who is Lilaa and what is her official or unofficial role on the project?
How is feedback from her and other non-coders integrated into the development process?
Can you describe the 'before and after' of the camera change prompted by her feedback?

open_questions.context: Kaze is preparing a talk for a tech conference about reverse engineering and hacking N64 games. He describes it as being about 'doing things differently than you would just expect in the industry'.
questions: What is the name of this conference and how did they approach you to be a speaker?
What is the core message you want to convey to an industry audience about the homebrew and romhacking scene?
How are you preparing for this talk differently than you would for a YouTube video?

open_questions.context: Kaze wants to make a very difficult final level but is concerned about frustrating players. He mentions that having a large buffer of total stars in the game might make a 'Kaizo'-style final level more acceptable.
questions: What is your core philosophy on difficulty in game design?
What would a 'fuck and fuck kaizo boss level' in RTYI look like?
How do you balance creating a challenge for hardcore fans while keeping the game accessible enough for a broader audience to finish?

open_questions.topic: Past Community Controversies and Their Impact
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that people were 'really upset' about a past clip he uploaded related to 'Chaz', which makes him hesitant to remake his politically-themed hack 'Super Trump 64'.
questions: Can you tell us more about the 'Chaz' clip incident and the community reaction?
How has that experience influenced your approach to content and community management?
Does the fear of negative reaction affect the creative decisions you make for the game itself, or just for promotional content?
